items.title: üì∑ The pier at Seacliff is going to be demolished.
items.content_html:
The pier at Seacliff is going to be demolished. I know a lot of people grew to dislike the pier. I get it. It‚Äôs old. It‚Äôs decrepit (esp. post-being-cloven-in-twain earlier this year). It literally stinks up the neighborhoods around it. The SS Palo Alto, a cement ship, intentionally grounded and taking on water since 1929, apparently was once a swanky place to eat. But no one really remembers that anymore. It‚Äôs just another disappointment of The Ugliest Pier.

But despite its shortcomings, I‚Äôm going to miss the pier. Years of beach days with the church, weaving in and out of its wooden legs. Walking barefoot on its planks and feeling each splinter tug at my skin, like a friendly pinch. Chatting with its pigeons and seagulls, and eyeing the water for a glimpse of a shark in the shallows.

At the end of the pier it felt like you could see the whole bay extend beyond you over the waters. You could hear the sounds of birthday party barbecues, and, cutting past the noise of the breaking waves, the soft sound of that one guy who plays the trumpet at Rio Del Mar.

It was a beautiful, messed up wreck. Maybe that‚Äôs why I liked it so much.

Attached are some snaps I took of the pier last year with my Canonet.

items.title: üçø White Noise, 2022 - ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ
items.content_html: <!-- raw HTML omitted -->
items.content_text:
Man‚Ä¶ there was a lot of good in this. The whole second chapter is fantastic. The scene at the gas station is perfection. There are some genuinely very funny moments. The end credits scene is hypnotic and wonderful. The entire film is shot beautifully. Danny Elfman‚Äôs score stole some scenes for me.

But the bad‚Ä¶ the stilted dialogue. The poor pacing. The constant philosophizing about every mundane thing. I haven‚Äôt read the book, and I don‚Äôt have a plan to. I‚Äôve heard it‚Äôs good and I trust that. The dialogue here seems like it would work much better in a format where you can stop for a moment and ponder over what someone just said rather than just barreling through to the next thing. It‚Äôs like Baumbach tried to fit as many lines from the book in each square millimeter of film as possible.¬†It just didn‚Äôt work for me. What could be some interesting tidbits of truth turn into a downpour of pompous pontifications, pounding away at the point, duh, death‚Äôs at the door and you‚Äôre feeling down. So what? It‚Äôs all a distraction from the truest question in life, which of course is:¬†Do sheep have lashes?

items.content_html:
Great writing by Julia Pott on the nature of pencils. I appreciate the way her newsletters deeply examine the ordinary. Especially love this quote of a quote:

One would imagine that in the era of computers, the pencil and notepad would have gone obsolete, but quite the opposite. If you walk down a High street, more often than not you‚Äôll encounter a stationary shop, and if you wander inside, as I always do, you‚Äôll find yourself getting lost in all the different writing implements and papers and potentials in front of you. Writer and technologist Kevin Kelly once claimed that ‚Äúspecies of technology‚Äù are immortal, even if they no longer have an obvious use:

With very few exceptions, technologies don‚Äôt die. In this way, they differ from biological species, which in the long-term inevitably do go extinct. The invention of the lightbulb meant that people stopped using candles to light their homes, but the candle didn‚Äôt die - its purpose simply changed. It moved from technology to art, and we see it now as romantic rather than a gloomy fire hazard. The crackly imperfection of vinyl became the warmth and charm of the object when compared to the CD or MP3. The limitations of stationary - the fact that ink can smudge or that a page from the notebook can tear - are also part of its appeal.

items.title: üçø Avatar: The Way of Water, 2022 - ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ
items.content_html: <!-- raw HTML omitted -->
items.content_text:
This had pretty much all the failings of its predecessor. Which means I still really greatly enjoyed it. Such a weird movie. Stunned by the beauty of the water, of course, but also by how long we just linger in the water with the characters. A lot of times films will have some very impressive shots but keep them short and sweet, or few and far between to stretch the budget. Clearly money was no object and James Cameron was like ‚Äúscrew it, let‚Äôs just play in the water for an hour‚Äù.

The action and tension is 100% a vehicle for more cool water scenes. And that‚Äôs fine! And the movie is clear that that‚Äôs the case. The whole engine/catalyst behind the events of the movie is pure popcorn sci-if cinema. Because it all just gets us back to playing in the water with our cool new alien friends. :)

items.content_html:
Quite fun. Story‚Äôs alright but mostly sits backseat to the gameplay. I grew up on the Jedi Knight games so it felt really good to get back to that type of Star Wars game. Nothing is quite as satisfying as force pushing a bunch of Storm Troopers off a ledge. üòå

I do think some of the criticism around level design makes sense. I thought it was mostly really great but there were a few repetitive moments in backtracking and such. I know they wanted it to feel like a cross between Dark Souls and Metroid, but I don‚Äôt know that the Metroidvania type level design lends itself as well to this kind of blockbuster storytelling. I‚Äôd rather they took an Uncharted 4 approach but ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è we‚Äôll see where the next one goes!

Random thoughts:
¬†-¬†Every time I watch this I think that maybe, just maybe, this time Brenda won‚Äôt snitch and she and Frank will run off and be a super con couple together.
- The casting in this is so good. Leo is really believable as Walken‚Äôs son. He brings that in his performance as well ‚Äì aside from the accent, there are some tics that are very subtle but very accurate to Christopher Walken.
- ‚ÄúWhat‚Äòs she gonna be? A shoe salesman at a centipede farm?‚Äù
- ‚ÄúFrank‚Ä¶ you‚Äôre not a Lutheran?‚Äù
- Throughout the year, if Anna and I are talking and someone who‚Äôs named Frank comes up in convo, I have like this muscle memory impulse to say ‚ÄúFrahnk. Frahnk. Hahd you pass the bah in Lwisiana Frahnk.‚Äù

Was talking with a friend about The Grand Budapest Hotel and came up with what I call the WATI (Wes Anderson Tolerance Index).

Weights your ratings of his films/shorts/ads based on runtime and averages the scores out. I have a relatively high WATI of 0.83.

Feel free to make a copy the Google Sheet and track your own WATI here.

items.title: üéÆ Disco Elysium: The Final Cut, 2021 - ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ
items.content_html: The best writing of any game I‚Äôve played, hands down. The world is so fascinating and original, textured and many-faceted. It takes a long time to get through (esp. with the voice acting - I can‚Äôt allow myself to cut people off) but I actually enjoyed taking it slow. Taking the scenic route, poking around in unlikely places for more information. There are a lot of subtle twists that happen through this - moments where my eyes were wide, waiting for the next turn in a tense conversation. Small, seemingly insignificant pieces of information can cause a ripple effect to dramatically shift the way you once perceived the story thus far, your character, and even the world you inhabit.

items.title: Really good post from Owen Dennis, creator of the late great Infinity Train, on the focus on existing IPs in entertainment
items.content_html:
At this point, the obsession over IP‚Äôs has been digging so deep that studios are pulling obscure IP‚Äôs out from decades ago that no one has ever heard of, which completely negates the original point of doing reboots and remakes of old IP‚Äôs in the first place. It‚Äôs just cringey and desperate feeling and I‚Äôm embarrassed on their behalf when I see it.

What‚Äôs even crazier is the amount of execs I‚Äôve met that don‚Äôt want to do this (all of them). I‚Äôm constantly told by execs that lament about how they wish they could make original stuff and not IP‚Äôs, but that their hands are tied. None of us got into this business so that we could remake old stuff. We didn‚Äôt watch some movie as an 8-year-old and say ‚ÄúWhen I grow up, I want to make this same exact movie but for a modern, four-quadrant audience, and as the jumping off point for an extended universe of films.‚Äù No one wants to do this, but for some reason, everyone in charge feels forced to.

I mean aren‚Äôt we all starting to laugh at and get bored by ‚Äúuniverses‚Äù? It‚Äôs alienating at this point, and a turn off, when you know that a movie or show you‚Äôre watching is just there to set up some other movie or season you‚Äôre supposed to watch later. You can really feel it in what you‚Äôre watching and it just feels gross. Let‚Äôs just make things we wanna watch now with an actual ending, then we won‚Äôt feel gross when we watch stuff and can just sit and enjoy it!

I think it‚Äôs a huge, joyless loss that an entire generation of artists are having their original, unique, and timely voices shifted almost entirely into the IP mines. A loss that I feel won‚Äôt be seen or understood fully for at least a decade, but when it happens, will feel like we‚Äôre missing an entire part of our collective souls.

Original post here.

items.title: The unexpectedly wonderful sensation of conforming an edit using Difference blend mode.
items.content_html:
In my video editing work, sometimes I need to make sure two videos match up perfectly, frame to frame. This could be for a variety of reasons, but today it was because I was conforming an edit that was done in Premiere Pro, to finish it with color and audio in DaVinci Resolve. ‚ÄúConforming‚Äù encompasses a lot of things, but for my purposes it basically means, ‚ÄúDid this timeline make it ok from one program to the other? Did anything break? Are all the shots lining up?

I usually start by firing off an export from the original app as a reference video, and lay that reference video on top of my imported timeline in Resolve. Then, I change its blend mode to ‚ÄúDifference.‚Äù That does exactly what you‚Äôd think ‚Äì it highlights the differences between the top and bottom clips in the timeline. So when I watch back the program, I should hope to see nothing but blackness, because everything matched up perfectly, right? ‚Ä¶right?

Shoot. Here I had a clip that used Premiere‚Äôs ‚ÄúModify ‚Üí Interpret Footage‚Äù workflow for slow motion, something that doesn‚Äôt carry over via XML to Resolve1. So I slowed my 30 FPS clip down to 80% and started slipping it left and right, frame by frame, until the most satisfying moment:

Ahhhh.

Conforming can be an annoying, frustrating experience at times, so I think it‚Äôs important to take a bit of joy in moments like these. Plus, sometimes clips with Difference blending that are slightly off sync can yield some cool results when in motion:

  1. If you‚Äôre still using this workflow, I highly recommend just learning to slow things down in the timeline by percentages. ‚ò∫Ô∏è There‚Äôs a whole bunch of issues in Premiere related to using Modify ‚Üí Interpret Footage for slow mo. If you edit in Final Cut you‚Äôre lucky because there‚Äôs a command for automating that! Search for ‚ÄúAutomatic Speed‚Äù in the keyboard shortcut customization window and bask in Apple‚Äôs occasional rightdoing with FCPX. ↩︎
items.content_text:
In my video editing work, sometimes I need to make sure two videos match up perfectly, frame to frame. This could be for a variety of reasons, but today it was because I was conforming an edit that was done in Premiere Pro, to finish it with color and audio in DaVinci Resolve. ‚Äú[Conforming](https://blog.frame.io/2019/03/29/conforming-with-resolve/)‚Äù encompasses a lot of things, but for my purposes it basically means, ‚ÄúDid this timeline make it ok from one program to the other? Did anything break? Are all the shots lining up?

I usually start by firing off an export from the original app as a reference video, and lay that reference video on top of my imported timeline in Resolve. Then, I change its blend mode to ‚ÄúDifference.‚Äù That does exactly what you‚Äôd think ‚Äì it highlights the differences between the top and bottom clips in the timeline. So when I watch back the program, I should hope to see nothing but blackness, because everything matched up perfectly, right? ‚Ä¶right?

![](https://cdn.uploads.micro.blog/90877/2022/f9521a25ab.gif)

Shoot. Here I had a clip that used [Premiere‚Äôs ‚ÄúModify ‚Üí Interpret Footage‚Äù workflow](https://helpx.adobe.com/premiere-pro/using/organizing-assets-project-panel.html#change_the_frame_rate_of_a_clip) for slow motion, something that doesn‚Äôt carry over via XML to Resolve[^1]. So I slowed my 30 FPS clip down to 80% and started slipping it left and right, frame by frame, until the most satisfying moment:

![](https://cdn.uploads.micro.blog/90877/2022/3f48ad4525.gif)

Ahhhh.

Conforming can be an annoying, frustrating experience at times, so I think it‚Äôs important to take a bit of joy in moments like these. Plus, sometimes clips with Difference blending that are slightly off sync can yield some cool results when in motion:

![](https://cdn.uploads.micro.blog/90877/2022/808bd01b2c.gif)

[^1]:	If you‚Äôre still using this workflow, I highly recommend just learning to slow things down in the timeline by percentages. ‚ò∫Ô∏è There‚Äôs a whole bunch of issues in Premiere related to using Modify ‚Üí Interpret Footage for slow mo. If you edit in Final Cut you‚Äôre lucky because there‚Äôs a command for automating that! Search for ‚ÄúAutomatic Speed‚Äù in the keyboard shortcut customization window and bask in Apple‚Äôs occasional rightdoing with FCPX.

Really surprised how much I enjoyed this. Although I wonder what it would‚Äôve been like with two leads that were actually singers. Not that they didn‚Äôt do a good job... but it definitely brought it down a notch. Patrick Page steals the show with one (half of a) song.

Then again, you‚Äôd miss out on the really fun winking humor Ferrell and Reynolds bring to it. Sometimes I wonder if I‚Äôm getting fatigued by that style of tongue-firmly-buried-in-the-cheek humor. I mean, it‚Äôs pretty much Reynolds‚Äô typecast at this point. But this felt fun to me, and genuine in a way that, say,¬†Free Guy¬†wasn‚Äôt.

I do want to say... there‚Äôs a certain plot point towards the end of Act Two that‚Äôs just... üëÄ. A bit roughly handled.

I‚Äôve immediately forgotten all the music but I didn‚Äôt completely hate it in the moment! And I‚Äôm a real sucker for that final shot. üíï Merry Christmas!

items.title: Black Panther: Wakanda Forever, 2022 - ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ¬Ω
items.content_html: <!-- raw HTML omitted -->
items.content_text:
We need the MCU to go smaller(1). This feels like a story torn between two movies: one an emotional drama about losing a loved one and a leader that needs to deliver on a promise to provide solace and introspection to the audience, the other a blockbuster action flick that needs to deliver on a promise to provide spectacle to the audience. Ultimately it underdelivers in both camps. I feel as though Ryan Coogler wanted to make a more intimate Shuri-focused film, evidenced by several scenes that feel integral to her development as a character but maybe not relevant to the development of the primary storyline with Namor. There‚Äôs just too much going on that steals that focus away, with Ironheart and Julia-Louis Dreyfuss‚Äôs storylines in particular tugging away at the frayed edges. By the time the video-game-action-figure-green-screen-epic-battle rolls around, I knew it was time to finally take that pee break(2) because nothing would happen for the next ten minutes.

(1) Not like Quantumania.
(2) I do not recommend watching a movie about ocean people with liquid bombs and trickling, gurgling sfx when ya gotta go üòï

items.content_text: Absolutely zany, but like the best Aardman films, the zaniness manages to be tasteful. Some of the funniest gags in a Christmas movie for sure. It's a bit of an information overload at times with hyper visuals and quick-firing dialogue (a similar feeling I had watching The Mitchells vs. The Machines... am I just getting old?) but overall very sweet, very funny, and very much going to be a Christmas staple from here on out.

items.title: Carol, 2015 - ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ¬Ω (contains spoilers)
items.content_html: <!-- raw HTML omitted -->
items.content_text:
This review may contain spoilers.

When you find someone you love so much, it‚Äôs easy to clam up. To become wooden. To have dry lips. To actually tremble at the thought of reaching out your hand to them. In Carol‚Äôs early moments, Therese is literally stunned by Carol in this way. Clearly she‚Äôs attracted. But she can‚Äôt make a move ‚Äì how could she in her¬†presence?¬†Carol recognizes this and guides her gently along by the shoulder. She makes the moves and Therese follows willingly.

The grammar of the film makes this tension so insanely palpable. The soft focus on the even softer fur of Carol‚Äôs coat. The way we watch her fingers depress the buttons on the dashboard. How loud every small sound is in the room with her. Everything works together to beckon Therese to follow.

In the end, Therese doesn‚Äôt follow. She rejects Carol‚Äôs propositions. Instead, she approaches Carol on her own terms, each on level footing, with an endless sunrise ahead.

items.title: Big Thief stole my heart
items.content_html:
If you aren‚Äôt yet acquainted with Big Thief and by extension Adrianne Lenker, I suggest you have some acquaintin‚Äô to do. They make delightful music that walks the line between folk & rock & electronic & country & most of the subgenres within. Their latest album has been on my rotation all year. Plus it has the dorkiest cover.

When I first heard them I was like ‚ÄúYeah whatever, you‚Äôre sort of pitchy.‚Äù But now they‚Äôre one of the few bands I call myself a fan of.

A few of my favorites:

  • Mary. A quiet storybook hymn. Best enjoyed with headphones in a dark room.
  • Shark Smile. Contains the most wonderful ‚Äúwoo!‚Äù
  • No Reason. Listen for the sing-along chorus. Stick around for the sick flute solo.
  • Two Hands. Clappity clap clap. Great percussion.
  • Time Escaping. Bonkers track.
  • Terminal Paradise. Really great build.
  • Red Moon. Leans hard into hoedown mode. That link is a video of them recording it live.

And a handful from Adrianne:

  • from. Just haunting. Get‚Äôs the full band treatment also.
  • not a lot, just forever. Really sweet love song. Makes me swoon.
  • forwards beckon rebound. Showcases Adrianne‚Äôs rhythmic fingerpicking.

items.title: I guess I‚Äôm doing this now.
items.content_html:
I was born too late to know the height of blogs in the mid-00s. However I have seen Julie & Julia and I do have delusions of grandeur. So here I am. Where once I simply tweeted my thoughts into the abyss, I shall now blog them furiously into an even abyssier abyss. I‚Äôll probably regret it üëç

Hoping to blog about all sorts of things. Whatever‚Äôs interesting to me, I guess. I imagine it‚Äôll mostly revolve around video editing, which I do for a living. I also enjoy taking photos for fun, but I wouldn‚Äôt say I‚Äôm a photographer. Similarly, I‚Äôve recently been making a simple app for the Playdate called The Drawing Board, but I‚Äôm definitely not a developer. I love hearing developers talk tho, and love using beautiful apps. Currently, I‚Äôm typing this in Ulysses, which I haven‚Äôt cracked open since college. It‚Äôs refreshing. :)

See ya ‚úåÔ∏è

items.title: The Half of It, 2020 - ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ
items.content_html: <!-- raw HTML omitted -->
items.content_text:
Super uneven. Some very cute parts. Several not cute parts. It wants to be a deep and thoughtful will-they-won‚Äôt-they romance, but also a cheesy Netflick with canned sfx gasps and an ‚Äúand everyone clapped‚Äù moment.

When we watched the Dear Evan Hansen movie, I thought a lot about how hard it is to write a character that straddles the line between cringey-but-lovable weirdo and sociopathic weirdo. Evan Hansen is a sociopathic weirdo with very few redeeming qualities or reasons to root for him, Ben Platt‚Äôs dulcet tones be damned. So it‚Äôs hard to watch a film when you don‚Äôt buy the lead role. Or in The Half of It, the supporting role. Paul is a moron. Not really a likable moron. Just a moron.

Maybe I‚Äôm being hard on him. I thought Daniel Diemer did fine with the cards he was dealt. Actually all the actors were fine, with Leah Lewis really bringing it. But the writing does Diemer‚Äôs character especially dirty. Maybe in a dumber high school film his character would shine more. But this is a film that quotes Sartre and Camus, and features a classic film geek dad, rich set design and legitimately gorgeous shot composition. Ellie sets a bar for romancing Aster that Paul could never meet, and the film‚Äôs production design sets a bar for quality that the writing could never meet.

items.title: MCU Ranked
items.content_html: <!-- raw HTML omitted -->
items.content_text:
Ok look it‚Äôs not the greatest thing to sweep cinema but several of these are halfway decent and I need something to talk to my family about.

  1. Avengers: Endgame

    A great way to go ‚Äúout‚Äù. Takes its time to examine grief and loss in a way that‚Äôs surprising from such a blockbuster. Star Wars Episode IX‚Ä¶ take notes.

  2. Loki
  3. The Avengers

    Didn‚Äôt like this when it first came out, but honestly it‚Äôs fantastic. This feels like the best time the MCU fully cashed in on the sensation of so many different heroes with really unique strengths and abilities. Well choreographed, and comparable to Incredibles¬†when it comes to good superhero fight scenes. Do wish the Chitauri were more visually interesting. Would have made it a 4.5 honestly.

  4. Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2
  5. Hawkeye
  6. WandaVision
  7. Captain America: Civil War

    Feels like a precursor to Endgame in the way it drastically shifts the tone of the whole Marvel Universe. Zemo is critically underdeveloped, but the focus on diplomacy and fallout of our heroes‚Äô and antiheroes‚Äô actions gives the film a great sense of emotional weight.

  8. Iron Man 3
  9. Ms. Marvel
  10. Shang-Chi and the Legend of the Ten Rings

...plus 23 more. View the full list on Letterboxd.

items.content_html:
ok, soap box time.

my wife (!) opened her gallery show this week to cap off her bachelor’s of fine arts program. anna poured so much effort into this show, pretty much just hitting the ground running right after our honeymoon. through so much difficulty (getting dropped from all her classes, an earlier show date than expected, advisors not showing up for meetings, artwork falling off the walls, and much much more), she has stayed so strong and determined to finish this semester well. i’m so so proud of her, and this show is a triumph and testament to her hard work throughout her school career.

i love you @annakatherine. i can’t wait to see where your art takes you (and us!)

items.content_html: Anna has the most empathetic heart I’ve ever known. She sees your sadness and is sad with you. She sees your happiness and magnifies it like a kaleidoscope. When you’re upset or stressed out or anxious she sees that and she understands you deeply. This joy she brings through this gift can turn any bad day into a good one, and any good day into a great one. . She is perhaps my favorite person in the world, and I am so thankful that she’s a part of my life. . Here’s to one trip around the sun, and to the many more yet to come. . . . #froggyandoldtoad

items.content_html: [To be read in a forties newsreel voice.] Stephen embarks tomorrow for the strange, far-off land know to some as “Sea-cattle”. Little is known about this fog-obscured country, but valiant Stephen fights the odds and journeys into the mists of the unknown to find the elusive “Dugri im-Arkiting”. Along the way, he will use his knowledge of the Instant-Gramp to find new faces to document, and to discover new and hap places to drink the native “ko-fee”. Nevertheless, he must leave, and a single tear falls from this humble reporter’s eye. Until next time, Stephen, and good luck on your courageous adventure into the mystery of “gru-wing ohp”.

items.content_html: Worship music bugs me. Sometimes it’s just too happy. Or too fake-happy, or something. I wish more faith-based bands wrote songs like the Psalms. Where sometimes David really does sing the praises of God, and really is genuinely happy. But other times his songs are filled with doubt and uncertainty and crying out for help. I understand singing worship songs in church, kind of as a pick-me-up, but listening to them at home feels so inauthentic sometimes, because sometimes I don’t feel the happiness or the belief that the songs sing. The song “Casimir Pulaski Day” by Sufjan Stevens is by no means a worship song, but in some ways I feel like it sounds more like a Psalm than anything worship artists are putting out. It ends with “He takes and He takes and He takes”. It’s important to know that other believers are feeling doubt and anger too. Because we all feel it, and denying that is lying to the entire Church. Anyways, that rant was probably way too long, but it’s something that’s been on my mind.

items.content_html:
My dear Oma gently passed away early this morning. When I heard the news, I was honestly filled with joy. Where she is now is so much better than anything she could have experienced here. She lived a very full life, and now she’s living an even fuller eternity.

She kept a journal for a while and in one of the entries she wrote, “It makes such a difference when one believes that we live only a short time on this earth, but an eternity in heaven. And the comfort we have that one day we will see our loved ones again. I wonder if they are helping to prepare a place for us.”

items.content_html: Remember the days when I regularly posted photos and didn’t wait several weeks between posts? I’ve just been so preoccupied with school and music and movie-making and tests and animations and existential crises and a whole slew of fun and not-fun life-stuff. Beginning to focus on actually living my life, and part of me is afraid of that, y’know? Life’s intimidating, so I feel like I tend to use Instagram or Facebook to escape my life, when it’s really best to face it head on. That’s how we grow. Okay, so yeah: picture of candles = existential caption. Sorry bout that.

items.content_html:
Today I’m saying goodbye to my Oma as she flys up to Oregon to live the rest of her foreseeable days with my aunt.

Oma has Alzheimer’s disease, and it’s been heartbreaking to see her decline. My dad said last night that we’ve essentially been watching her die a little every day.

Yesterday, we had a little family get-together to eat delicious food and say goodbye to Oma. She was so tired. Eventually she started heading to bed, and right before she settled in for the night, we prayed over her and hugged her. She was practically falling over, she was so tired, but if there’s one thing that would keep Oma awake, it’s hugs. She could hug forever and ever and never get tired of it. Right after I hugged her and kissed her goodnight, she stuttered something like “I- I… la… lof.” We were upstairs laughing and crying and reminiscing and such when Oma woke up and meandered upstairs. When she saw us all she quickly realized it wasn’t morning and that she’d only been asleep about an hour. She laughed a little at that, and said things like “oh” and “psh”, and would point at us all and smile.

We all told her that it was okay and she ended up hugging a few of us again. Then, mid-hug, she pointed at her head and said, with quite a bit of strength, “is- is s-stupa!” We all of course comforted her and told her she wasn’t stupid, and she’d say “yes, yes” and we’d say “no, no” and such. After a few tears and hugs, my mom led us all in a chorus of “When We All Get To Heaven” and Oma joined in and danced a little. Then we sent her to bed.

I don’t know how many more days I’ll be able to see my Oma here on Earth. But I’m immeasurably excited to spend eternity with her. I want to listen to all her stories, I want to hear her funny Swiss accent, I want to see her as a beautiful young woman again. “When we all get to Heaven, What a day of rejoicing that will be. When we all see Jesus, We’ll sing and shout the victory!”

items.content_html: Meet Milton, the cat with thumbs. Actually, Milton is a polydactyl cat, which means he was born with a genetic mutation that gives him extra toes. Milton lies out on the bike path I use to get home every now and then, and each time has rubbed against my leg when I stop, and let’s me scratch his head. He also runs after me when I leave, which makes it oh so hard to go. Thank you, Milton, for making my trip back home so much cooler. #storyportrait

items.content_html: Dawn and dusk are my favorite times of day. Not because of the light, in fact I prefer the times just before or after the good light. I like these times because the world seems to be in transition from the hustle-and-bustle of high noon and the sound sleep of midnight. These bookends of the day are when the world is the most peaceful, when everything is surreally real, and when I feel like I’ve got nothing I need to do but enjoy the view.

items.content_html: They’re in looooove. (Last night we swam with manta rays. The most beautiful thing I’ve seen in the ocean. There were all these scuba divers with lights pointed up and these huge schools of fish were swimming through the lights and there was plankton everywhere and a bunch of bubbles from the scuba divers and it was like an underwater light show. Unforgettable.)
